rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 6    Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 20   Value: 12
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 13   Value: 17
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 14   Value: 25
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 9    Value: 39
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
rounds.response:
Turn 1

I look over my ledger:

- Wheat 6 → 6 total  
- Wood 20 → 12 total  
- Sheep 13 → 17 total  
- Brick 14 → 25 total  
- Ore 9 → 39 total  

Total value = 6 + 12 + 17 + 25 + 39 = 99.

My most valuable single resource is Ore (39 pts for 9 cards), coming out to ≈ 4.33 value per Ore.  
Brick is next at 25 pts for 14 cards, or ≈ 1.79 per Brick.  
The cheap ones are Wheat (1 per Wheat) and Wood (0.6 per Wood).  
Sheep sits in the middle at ≈ 1.31 per Sheep.

Trading goal: get richer—specifically I want more high-value stuff (Brick & Ore) while dumping low-value Wood/Wheat.  
That means I should aggressively trade away Wood (0.6) and Wheat (1) for Brick (1.79) or Ore (4.33).  
A ratio like 4 Wood for 2 Brick yields me +1.58 value while my opponent might still like it if they value Wood higher.

Message to Player 1:

"Hey! I’m overloaded on Wood (20) and could use more Brick & Ore. How about 4 Wood for 2 Brick to get things rolling?"

[Offer: 4 Wood -> 2 Brick]

rounds.response:
After the first round I’ve learned three things:
- Player 1 turned down 4 Wood asking for only 2 Brick, so Brick seems even more valuable to them than it already is to me.
- They didn’t propose any counter-offer, which may indicate they’re content with their hand or are still feeling me out.
- My total value is 99 and my biggest surpluses (relative to their weight in my current value) are Wood (20 units, carrying only 12 points) and Wheat (6 units, only 6 points). Brick and Ore feel scarce—Brick (14 units, 25 points) is already worth more per unit than anything except Ore.

Therefore, I need to offer something Player 1 values less than Brick while still sweetening the pot. A 1-for-1 Brick swap seems unlikely to succeed. Instead, I’ll package some of my bulky Wood with a more attractive Ore to buy Brick at the least cost.

[Offer: 5 Wood, 1 Ore -> 3 Brick, 1 Sheep]

rounds.response:
Let’s recap my current situation.

Current holdings (after no trades have happened yet)

Resource | Qty | Value/item | Total value
Wheat    |  6  | 6         | 36
Wood     | 20  | 12        | 240
Sheep    | 13  | 17        | 221
Brick    | 14  | 25        | 350
Ore      |  9  | 39        | 351
Total portfolio value = 36+240+221+350+351 = 1 198

What just happened  

Turn 1 I offered 4 Wood → 2 Brick, rejected.  
Turn 2 I offered 5 Wood+1 Ore → 3 Brick+1 Sheep, rejected.  

Interpretation of those rejections  
- Player 1 clearly values Brick highly and/or is short on Wood/Ore.  
- My proposals were asking for too large a slice of his Brick for what I was giving.

Next move (Turn 3, still me to offer)  
I need to make it more attractive and be more flexible on the goods I accept.

Insight  
Brick enjoys the biggest marginal gain for me (25 value per unit) and 14 isn’t an enormous stash, so continuing to pursue Brick is sensible.  
Ore (39 value) is my single most efficient chip; giving it away hurts, so any Ore I offer must be offset by very favorable gains.

Proposed trade for Turn 3  
[Offer: 2 Ore, 5 Wood → 4 Brick, 1 Wheat]

Why I hope it might be accepted  
- Going rate Catan-style is “2-for-1” for like resources; this is getting 4 Brick (value 100) plus 1 Wheat (value 6) in exchange for 2 Ore (value 78) + 5 Wood (value 60) = 138.  
- I’m over-paying by 32 on my metric, but because Brick is scarce and I have tons of Wood (20) and decent Ore (9), the marginal loss is acceptable.

Net value if accepted  
Give up 138, receive 106 → net asset-drop now of 32, but my Brick stock jumps from 14 to 18. Future trades can convert that Brick surplus into other scarce items if I wish.

rounds.response:
Let me assess my current situation.

My present inventory and total value:
- Wheat   6 @ 1 each → value 6  
- Wood   20 @ 0.6 each → value 12  
- Sheep 13 @ 1.31 each → value 17  
- Brick 14 @ 1.79 each → value 25  
- Ore    9 @ 4.33 each → value 39  

Total value = 6 + 12 + 17 + 25 + 39 = 99  
My least-valuable resource is Wood (0.6 per unit), while Ore is most-valuable (4.33 per unit).  
Brick is second-best at 1.79—Player 1 seems reluctant to part with it, so I may need to overpay.

I also note Player 1 has never counter-offered, so I’m the one who needs to keep proposing.  
To increase my total value, I should look to either:
1. Upgrade Wood into any non-Wood resource, or  
2. Upgrade Wheat/Sheep into higher-value Brick/Ore.

I’ll make a new, more generous offer that gives away several Wood while asking for Brick only.

[Offer: 6 Wood → 2 Brick]
